content: The "local universe" splitting is the left adjoint splitting L:Fib⁡S→[Sop,Cat⁡]L:\operatorname{Fib}_{\mathscr S}\to [\mathscr S^{op},\operatorname{Cat}]L:FibS​→[Sop,Cat] of a Grothendieck fibration. Does somebody happen to know if LLL is compatible with base change? When F:S′→SF:\mathscr S'\to \mathscr SF:S′→S is a functor, will L(F∗C)L(F^\ast C)L(F∗C) be isomorphic to F∗(LC)F^\ast (LC)F∗(LC)?

Mike Shulman said:

Nope. (-:

They won't be isomorphic?

Think about it: an object of L(F∗C)L(F^*C)L(F∗C) in the fiber over x∈S′x\in \mathcal{S}'x∈S′ is an object y∈S′y\in \mathcal{S}'y∈S′, a morphism x→yx\to yx→y, and an object a∈C(F(y))a\in C(F(y))a∈C(F(y)). While an object of F∗(LC)F^*(LC)F∗(LC) in the fiber over xxx is an object of LCLCLC in the fiber over F(x)F(x)F(x), which is an object z∈Sz\in \mathcal{S}z∈S, a morphism f(x)→zf(x)\to zf(x)→z, and an object b∈C(z)b\in C(z)b∈C(z).

Mike Shulman said:

Think about it: an object of L(F∗C)L(F^*C)L(F∗C) in the fiber over x∈S′x\in \mathcal{S}'x∈S′ is an object y∈S′y\in \mathcal{S}'y∈S′, a morphism x→yx\to yx→y, and an object a∈C(F(y))a\in C(F(y))a∈C(F(y)). While an object of F∗(LC)F^*(LC)F∗(LC) in the fiber over xxx is an object of LCLCLC in the fiber over F(x)F(x)F(x), which is an object z∈Sz\in \mathcal{S}z∈S, a morphism f(x)→zf(x)\to zf(x)→z, and an object b∈C(z)b\in C(z)b∈C(z).

You are right, the fibers look very different. Is it possible that I have more luck with the right adjoint splitting Sp⁡\operatorname{Sp}Sp, at least for reindexings along functors S/Δ→S/Γ\mathscr S/\Delta\to \mathscr S/\GammaS/Δ→S/Γ induced by morphisms u:Δ→Γu:\Delta \to \Gammau:Δ→Γ in the base? Because if p:C→S/Γp:C\to \mathscr S/\Gammap:C→S/Γ is a fibration and v:Θ→Δv:\Theta \to \Deltav:Θ→Δ is an object in S/Δ\mathscr S/\DeltaS/Δ, then Sp⁡(u∗p)(v)=FibS/Δ(y(v),u∗p)\operatorname{Sp}(u^\ast p)(v) = Fib_{\mathscr S/\Delta}(y(v),u^\ast p)Sp(u∗p)(v)=FibS/Δ​(y(v),u∗p) while u∗(Sp⁡p)(v)=(Sp⁡p)(uv)=FibS/Γ(y(uv),p)u^\ast (\operatorname{Sp} p)(v) = (\operatorname{Sp} p)(uv) = Fib_{\mathscr S/\Gamma}(y(uv),p)u∗(Spp)(v)=(Spp)(uv)=FibS/Γ​(y(uv),p). If I did no mistake then I should get the picture below
Screenshot-2023-10-11-011414.png
I feel like that I should get FibS/Δ(y(v),u∗p)≅FibS/Γ(y(uv),p)Fib_{\mathscr S/\Delta}(y(v),u^\ast p) \cong Fib_{\mathscr S/\Gamma}(y(uv),p)FibS/Δ​(y(v),u∗p)≅FibS/Γ​(y(uv),p) from that, but I am not exactly sure.

If RRR denotes the right adjoint splitting, then an object of R(F∗C)R(F^*C)R(F∗C) in the fiber over xxx consists of, for every yyy and morphism y→xy\to xy→x, an object of in the fiber of CCC over F(y)F(y)F(y), plus some isomorphisms. Whereas an object of F∗(RC)F^*(RC)F∗(RC) in the fiber over xxx is an object in the fiber of RCRCRC over F(x)F(x)F(x), which consists of, for every zzz and morphism z→F(x)z\to F(x)z→F(x), an object in the fiber of CCC over zzz, plus some isomorphisms. They don't look the same to me, and I don't see why FFF being the induced functor between a pair of slice categories should matter.

Mike Shulman said:

If RRR denotes the right adjoint splitting, then an object of R(F∗C)R(F^*C)R(F∗C) in the fiber over xxx consists of, for every yyy and morphism y→xy\to xy→x, an object of in the fiber of CCC over F(y)F(y)F(y), plus some isomorphisms. Whereas an object of F∗(RC)F^*(RC)F∗(RC) in the fiber over xxx is an object in the fiber of RCRCRC over F(x)F(x)F(x), which consists of, for every zzz and morphism z→F(x)z\to F(x)z→F(x), an object in the fiber of CCC over zzz, plus some isomorphisms. They don't look the same to me, and I don't see why FFF being the induced functor between a pair of slice categories should matter.

It should matter because (S/Δ)/v=(S/Θ)(\mathscr S/\Delta)/v=(\mathscr S/\Theta)(S/Δ)/v=(S/Θ) so that the (morphisms with codomain vvv in S/Δ\mathscr S/\DeltaS/Δ) = (morphisms with codomain Θ\ThetaΘ in S\mathscr SS) = (morphisms with codomain uvuvuv in S/Γ\mathscr S/\GammaS/Γ).
This means that an object in the (v:Θ→Δ)(v:\Theta \to \Delta)(v:Θ→Δ) th fiber of Ru∗CRu^\ast CRu∗C consists of an object in C(uv)C(uv)C(uv) plus for every w:Ξ→Θw: \Xi \to \Thetaw:Ξ→Θ an object in C(uvw)C(uvw)C(uvw) plus some isomorphisms. Similarly an object in the (v:Θ→Δ)(v:\Theta \to \Delta) (v:Θ→Δ) th fiber of u∗RCu^\ast RCu∗RC consists of an object in (RC)(uv)(RC)(uv)(RC)(uv) which is the same thing as an object in C(uv)C(uv)C(uv) plus for each morphism w:Ξ→Θw:\Xi \to \Thetaw:Ξ→Θ some object in C(uvw)C(uvw)C(uvw) plus some isomorphisms. So the same data on both sides?
Ah, I see what you're saying. That seems possible, though I haven't checked the details.
